Null Expected is a QA thought hub. It's where practitioners question the status quo, unpack the trade-offs of "done," and advocate for software that doesn't just pass, but deserves to.
We built this space because too much QA content either simplifies the role ("just write test cases") or drowns it in tools and jargon. We wanted somewhere that:

ul.li: Reflects the real-world messiness of testing in modern teams

div.div: "Quality is a mindset, not a metric."

div.p: This isn't a tutorials site — though you will find actionable advice.
This isn't just opinion — though you will find strong ones.
that evolve with teams
on the role of QA
from the trenches and leadership
Because QA is the only discipline that celebrates a null result — when things don't crash, don't regress, don't surprise us.
But we also know that behind every "null" there's an expectation, a person, and a decision.

div.h2: A Note on the Voices Behind the Site
div.p: While the blog is shaped by QA professionals with different experiences, this is not a personal blog. Our bios live elsewhere. What matters here is the thinking, not the résumé.
That said — we're practitioners. This site is our way of giving back, challenging forward, and documenting what it means to build for quality, not just test it.
We write from experience — and we edit each other ruthlessly.
Because quality isn't accidental — and silence still speaks.

div.style: max-width: 800px; margin: 0 auto 5rem; padding: 0 1rem; text-align: center;

div.p: We are QA professionals, thinkers, and skeptics.
We don't just check that software works — we question what "working" really means.
We believe that testing is not a phase, a script, or a checkbox.
It's a way of seeing.
Because a passing test without purpose is just noise.
100% test coverage doesn't mean 100% confidence.
QA should enable, not block.
We ask "why" even when the spec says "done."
Tools change. Thinking doesn't.
A "null" result isn't nothing — it's trust, verified.
This is what drives Null:Expected. A QA thought hub, always in beta.
We're QA professionals with different voices, shared curiosity, and far too many opinions about software quality. This is our thought hub — part roadmap, part portfolio, always in beta.
Senior QA Engineer

With over 8 years in QA, Jane specializes in test automation frameworks and performance testing. She's passionate about building scalable testing strategies and mentoring junior QA professionals. When she's not debugging test flakes, you'll find her exploring new testing tools or speaking at QA conferences.
QA Lead & Strategy Consultant

Alex brings 10+ years of experience in quality strategy and team leadership. He's worked across startups and enterprise organizations, focusing on quality culture transformation and process optimization. Alex is known for his pragmatic approach to QA and his ability to translate technical concepts into business value.
Our individual bios live here, but the Manifesto speaks for what drives us.
Null:Expected is a play on a software testing term — where "null" means nothing is returned, and that's the expected result.
But in QA, even that "nothing" is deliberate. It reflects a decision, a rule, or a user expectation.
The name reminds us that behind every outcome — even silence — there's intent, and quality depends on understanding that.

We believe that the best QA insights come from real-world experience, honest reflection, and the willingness to challenge conventional wisdom. Our posts aren't just theoretical—they're battle-tested strategies and hard-earned lessons from the trenches.

Whether we're exploring the psychology of bug hunting, dissecting the latest testing frameworks, or debating the future of quality assurance, we bring both expertise and curiosity to every conversation.
